docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont and chairman of the Judiciary Committee, and 18 other senators sent a letter to President Obama and Democratic Congressional leaders on Wednesday urging them to repeal the limited exemption for insurers from federal antitrust laws in the final version of major health care legislation. Mr. Leahy had put forward a proposal to repeal the antitrust exemption, which was approved by Congress in 1945. But the proposal was dropped from the Senate version of the health care bill because of opposition from Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska. Mr. Nelson is a former state insurance commissioner and insurance company executive.
docs.abstract: Senate Judiciary Committee chairman Patrick Leahy and 18 other senators send letter urging Pres Obama and Democratic Congressional leaders to repeal limited exemption for insurers from federal antitrust laws, approved by Congress in 1945, in final version of health care legislation (S)
docs.snippet: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont and chairman of the Judiciary Committee, and 18 other senators sent a letter to President Obama and Democratic Congressional leaders on Wednesday urging them to repeal the limited exemption for insurers...

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the independent Democrat from Connecticut, is taking issue with Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, for feeling double-crossed by Mr. Lieberman during critical negotiations over the health care bill.

headline.main: Lieberman Disputes Reid's Account of Health Bill Wrangling

docs.abstract: The Connecticut senator, who had objected to several provisions in the Senate's bill on health-care legislation, takes issue with the majority leader's assessment of his views on a Medicare proposal.
docs.snippet: The Connecticut senator, who had objected to several provisions in the Senate's bill on health-care legislation, takes issue with the majority leader's assessment of his views on a Medicare proposal.

docs.lead_paragraph: With Congress grappling to unify House and Senate health bills, Tom Daschle, the former Senate majority leader, was on the West Coast Wednesday, making his predictions for the final bill.

headline.main: Daschle Handicaps the Final Health Bill

docs.abstract: At an investor conference, Tom Daschle offers predictions about the final health care legislation.
docs.snippet: At an investor conference, Tom Daschle offers predictions about the final health care legislation.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama and Congressional Democratic leaders have spent much of Wednesday holed up at the White House in a marathon negotiating session aimed at resolving differences between the House and Senate on sweeping health legislation that could cover more than 30 million uninsured Americans.

headline.main: Obama and Democratic Leaders in Marathon Negotiations

docs.abstract: Differences over the House and Senate health care bills are being ironed out in an extraordinary day of negotiations at the White House, sources said.
docs.snippet: Differences over the House and Senate health care bills are being ironed out in an extraordinary day of negotiations at the White House, sources said.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont and chairman of the Judiciary Committee, and 18 other senators on Wednesday sent a letter to President Obama and Democratic Congressional leaders urging them to repeal the limited exemption for insurers from federal antitrust laws as part of the final version of major health care legislation.

headline.main: Senators Call for Repeal of Insurers' Antitrust Exemption

docs.abstract: Nineteen senators urged the repeal of the insurance industry's exemption from laws against price fixing and bid rigging.
docs.snippet: Nineteen senators urged the repeal of the insurance industry's exemption from laws against price fixing and bid rigging.

docs.lead_paragraph: David Brooks: Gail, can I draw you into the America versus Europe debate? This is the old argument over which model of capitalism is better, the Anglo-American model or the continental one. It was recently rekindled by two bloggers extraordinaire -- Jim Manzi and Jonathan Chait -- and then joined by our colleague Paul Krugman.
docs.abstract: Which model of capitalism is better?
docs.snippet: Which model of capitalism is better?

headline.main: Comparing the Bills, Part 2: Insurance Market Reforms

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Sheila Crowe, a professor in the division of gastroenterology and hepatology in the department of medicine at the University of Virginia, recently joined the Consults blog to answer reader questions about celiac disease, an often overlooked digestive disorder that causes damage to the small intestine when gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley and rye, is eaten. In previous posts, Dr. Crowe exploredthe varied symptoms of celiac disease and confirming a diagnosis of celiac disease. Here, Dr. Crowe responds to readers asking about the disease running in families, genetic tests that may help confirm a diagnosis, food allergies and thins that set off the ailment.
docs.abstract: Dr. Sheila Crowe responds to reader questions on genes and celiac disease.
docs.snippet: Dr. Sheila Crowe responds to reader questions on genes and celiac disease.

docs.lead_paragraph: To continue the conversation about why health care in America is so expensive and what the legislation emerging in Washington would or would not do about it, the Prescriptions blog asked Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, chairman of the Finance Committee and one of the leading architects of the Senate bill, to answer the same question that we posed earlier to two policy experts of different political persuasions.

headline.main: Baucus: Why Health Care Is Expensive

docs.abstract: The chairman of the Finance Committee takes part in our discussion about why health care costs so much.
docs.snippet: The chairman of the Finance Committee takes part in our discussion about why health care costs so much.
